title.narrative: Paris21 and SCB partnership- SDG Capacity development
Paris21 and SCB partnership- SDG Capacity development

description.narrative: Against the background of the Cape Town Global Action Plan (CPGAP), the overall objectives for the development intervention are; - Low and middle income countries have the possibility and capacity to participate in global dialogue and follow up on the 2030 Agenda. - Inclusive partnerships established, including low and middle income countries, that contribute to improving the use of data and statistics in the follow-up and global implementation of the 2030 Agenda. The specific objective for the development intervention is improved quality, availability and use of data and indicators in following up the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. In order to achieve this specific objective, the partners will work together over the next four years towards the following intermediate outcomes: - Improved knowledge and capacity among data users and producers (CTGAP 2, 4) - Improved global/regional dialogue and mutual learning across national statistical systems and the data ecosystem for better coordination and increased data use/demand (CTGAP 1, 5 and 6) - Increased capacity at national level to reduce data gaps and produce quality statistics through agile data planning processes (CTGAP 2, 3)

OECD/PARIS21 and Statistic Sweden, a specialist Swedish authority, have applied for funding of approximately SEK 40 000 000 to jointly carry out the “Global program to develop capacity in data and statistics for the 2030 Agenda” during the period 2019-2022.
The overall objectives for the intervention are:
1. Low and middle income countries have the possibility and capacity to participate in global dialogue and follow up on the 2030 Agenda.
2. Inclusive partnership established, including low and middle income countries, that contribute to improving the use of data and statistics in the follow-up and global implementation of the 2030-Agenda.
The specific objective for the development intervention is:
- Improved quality availability and use of data and indicators in following up on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
In order to achieve the specific objective, the partners will work together over the next four years towards the following intermediate outcomes:
- Improved knowledge and capacity among data users and producers. - Improved global/regional dialogue and mutual learning across national statistical systems and the data ecosystem for better coordination and increased data use/demand. - Increased capacity at national level to reduce data gaps and produce quality statistics through agile data planning processes.
The intervention is in line with PARIS21 Program of Work, which has a total annual budget of approximately 5 MEURO. The largest donors are DIFID, Switzerland and Canada. The Swedish contribution to OECD/PARIS 21 is approximately 6 MSEK over a four-year period, in total 24 MSEK. In addition, approximately 4 MSEK will annually be provided to Statistics Sweden, in total 16,4 MSEK. The total contribution is 40 400 000 SEK.

OECD/PARIS21 och SCB, en svensk myndighet med omfattade erfarenhet av bilateralt utvecklingsarbete inom statistik, har ansökt om finansiering på 40 miljoner kronor för att i partnerskap genomföra ett "Globalt program för att utveckla kapacitet i data och statistik för Agenda 2030" under perioden 2019-2022.
De övergripande målen för programmet är:
1. Låg- och medelinkomstländer har möjlighet och kapacitet att delta i global dialog och följa upp 2030-agendan.
2. Inkluderande partnerskap, inklusive låg- och medelinkomstländer, som bidrar till att förbättra användningen av data och statistik i uppföljningen och det globala genomförandet av 2030-agendan.
Det specifika målet för programmet är:
- Förbättrad tillgänglighet och användning av data och indikatorer för uppföljning av genomförandet av 2030-agendan.
För att uppnå det specifika målet ska parterna samarbeta mot följande resultat:
- Förbättrad kunskap och kapacitet bland användare av data och dataproducenter. - Förbättrad global/regional dialog och ömsesidigt lärande mellan nationella statistiska system och data-ekosystem för bättre samordning och ökad användning och efterfrågan av data. - Ökad kapacitet på nationell nivå för att minska datagap och producera statistik av hög kvalitet, genom agila dataplaneringsprocesser.
Programmet går i linje med PARIS21:s beslutade arbetsplan. Arbetsplanen har en total årlig budget på cirka 5 MEURO. De största givarna till OECD/PARIS21 är DIFID, Schweiz och Kanada.
Det svenska bidraget till OECD/PARIS21 är årligen cirka 6 MSEK över en fyraårsperiod, totalt 24 MSEK.
Utöver bidraget till OECD/PARIS21 kommer Sida att årligen avsätta cirka 4 MSEK för SCB som ska bidra till PARIS21 med sin specifika kompetens kring administrativa system/data, systematisk produktion av gender data, nationalräkenskaper och specifik kontextkunskap. SCB:s totala budget uppgår till 16,4 MSEK.
Den totala budgeten för denna insats uppgår till 40 400 000 SEK.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

17.18 - By 2020, enhance capacity-building support to developing countries, including for least developed countries and small island developing States, to increase significantly the availability of high-quality, timely and reliable data disaggregated by income, gender, age, race, ethnicity, migratory status, disability, geographic location and other characteristics relevant in national contexts

17.18 - By 2020, enhance capacity-building support to developing countries, including for least developed countries and small island developing States, to increase significantly the availability of high-quality, timely and reliable data disaggregated by income, gender, age, race, ethnicity, migratory status, disability, geographic location and other characteristics relevant in national contexts.

17.19 - By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries

17.19 - By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries.

title.narrative: Beslut om insats PARIS21 och SCB _ SDG Capacity Development

description.narrative: During 2019 the foundations for the partnership between Statistics Sweden and PARIS21 have been concretized, with the signing of an MoU and in-depth planning meetings. In 2019, PARIS21 directly engaged with 94 countries and hundreds of global, regional, country-level and local partners to make data more useful and to increase usage. PARIS21’s 2019 Programme of Work also supported 22 fragile states,18 small island developing states (SIDS) and included 23 National Strategies for the Development of Statistics (NSDS) and Regional Strategies for the Development of Statistics (RSDS) related activities. Besides global-level activities, the work of PARIS21 in 2019 directly impacted Africa, Asia and the Pacific, and Latin America and Caribbean countries and regional entities. Engagement in Africa was highest and accounted for 28% of all activities. Engagement in the Asia and Pacific region accounted for 21%, and 18% of the activities took place in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) Some highlights from PARIS21 in 2019 include; - All three of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of which PARIS21 is a custodian agency are prioritised as Tier 1 since 2019: 17.18.2 Number of countries that have national statistical legislation that complies with the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics 17.18.3 Number of countries with a national statistical plan that is fully funded and under implementation, by source of funding 17.19.1 Dollar value of all resources made available to strengthen statistical capacity in developing countries - PARIS21 became secretariat of the Bern Network on Financing Data for Development, a global alliance with over 140 members from aid and development agencies, NSOs, international organisations (IOs), private sector partnerships and civil societies. The Bern Network’s objective is to promote more and better financing for data so that sufficient data is available to support achievement of the SDGs. - To further support SDG monitoring PARIS21 has continued to support the growth and sustainability of this crucial area through its Capacity Development 4.0 workstream to support low and middle-income countries, and 2019 saw the launch of the Statistical Capacity Monitor, a unique, interactive tool featuring a wide range of performance indicators designed to facilitate quick analyses. - Gender has continued to be a key focus and has been integrated across PARIS21 workstreams, including ensuring that the gender statistics perspective has been fully integrated into NSDS workshops for NSS assessment, the PARIS21 Academy e-learning site, ADAPT and PRESS. - PARIS21 focused on putting modernisation and innovation at the heart of the NSS in 2019. PARIS21 delivered a new module on “Managing Innovation” to its leadership training scheme for NSO management. - The Advanced Data Planning Tool (ADAPT) was updated to include budgeting and costing features, as well as a gender module. The tool was employed by countries to help improve data gap assessments and to monitor data planning activities. - With Partners for Review, PARIS21 published a landmark paper identifying factors that prevent countries from fully exploiting their data ecosystem. PARIS21 also worked to empower countries to use citizen-generated data, and carried out pilots in the Philippines to empower NSOs to use new data sources. - PARIS21’s work on governance continued in 2019 through continued support to the Praia Group, were PARIS21 led the chapter on “Openness” in the Handbook which, once approved by the 51st United Nations Statistical Commission in 2020, will be a breakthrough for good data on governance During 2019 a new PARIS21 strategy has been drafted. Statistics Sweden has supported the drafting of the new strategy which was presented to the board at the annual meeting. In addition, Statistics Sweden and PARIS21 has developed a monitoring and evaluation framework for the joint programme, which resulted in a draft framework focusing on quantitative measures and qualitative “story-telling” for each intermediate outcome, focusing on Statistics Sweden’s contribution to initiatives. Highlights from Statistis Sweden include; -Statistics Sweden contributed to improving capacity among data producers and users in the area of gender statistics through input on content for PARIS21 e-learning course on “Communicating gender statistics”. - Assistance in developing a web platform for Agenda 2030 data in several low and middle income countries was provided in order to improve access for data users; - Expertise in developing guidelines for national statistical plans was provided to increase capacity at national level to identify and reduce data gaps and plan data production more effectively; - Contribution to the debate on the future financing of statistical development via OCED and PARIS21 initiatives; - Design of a project for improving disaggregation of SDGs by migratory status.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Capacity development, partnership and methods that support Agenda 2030 for sustainable development 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Kapacitetsutveckling, partnerskap och metoder som stöder Agenda 2030 för hållbar utveckling 2018-2022
